questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a painless mass in the neck (shown in the image). A 8-cm firm, movable tumor is identified at the angle of the left jaw. A biopsy of the tumor reveals myoepithelial cells intermingled with myxoid, mucoid, and cartilaginous areas. The tumor is removed surgically. Which of the following is the most likely prognosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is PLEOMORPHIC ADENOMA (Beingn mixed tumor)

  • The most common tumor of the salivary glands
  • Painless, slow-growing, benign neoplasm
  • Mobile, discrete masses within the parotid or submandibular areas or in the buccal cavity
  • Biphasic appearance (admixture of epithelial and stromal elements)
  • At surgery, tumor projections can be missed if the tumor is not carefully dissected.
  • Tumor implanted during surgery or tumor nodules left behind continue to grow as recurrences in the scar tissue of the previous operation.
  • The RATE OF RECURRENCE:-
  • Recurrence of pleomorphic adenoma represents local growth and does not reflect malignancy.
  • Recurrences occur months to years after surgery.
  • Recurrence following parotidectomy is about 4%.
  • Recurrence after simple enucleation approaches 25%, likely due to tumor extension beyond the capsule.
  • Malignant transformation (choice C) is exceedingly rare.
  • Correlate with age of the lesion
  • 2% of tumors that have been present for less than 5 years harbor cancers, but this increases to 10% for those present for more than 15 years.
  • Cancers are usually adenocarcinomas or undifferentiated carcinomas.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary gland; slow growing and painless.

Proliferation of myoepithelium in a mesenchymal stroma +/- epithelium;

Cells in ducts = epithelial, Cells not in ducts = myoepithelial

Mesenchymal stroma = chondroid stroma (specific), others (require epithelium) mucochondroid, hyalinized, osseous, fatty, myxoid

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman complains of a white discoloration in her Mouth. She has a 60-pack-year history of smoking. Physical Examination reveals white plaques on the buccal mucosa, Tongue, and floor of the mouth. A biopsy (shown in the image) Demonstrates severe epithelial dysplasia. The patient is at higher risk of developing which of the following neoplasms?
questions.solution:
SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA

  • Although the Probability of squamous cell carcinoma developing in a patient With oral leukoplakia is low, there is still a risk (10% to 12%) Of malignant transformation.
  • Carcinogenic factors that lead to the induction of cancer usually affect more than one site in the oral mucosa (multiple tumors)
  • Choices A, B, and C do not arise from the oral epithelium.
  • Carcinomas of the oral cavity are strongly associated with:-
    • Tobacco use, synergistic effect with alcohol.
    • Transplant recipients and HIV-positive patients are also at an increased risk, presumably as a result of immunosuppression.
    • Younger patients. Interestingly, carcinomas developing in HIV positive individuals are only infrequently associated with HPV infection
    • Syphilis, oral sepsis, iron deficiency, oral candidiasis, and Fanconi anemia.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the mouth, also known as oral squamous cell carcinoma, is the most prevalent form of oral cancer. It originates in the squamous cells lining the lips and the interior surfaces of the mouth, including the gums, tongue, inner cheeks, and the floor and roof of the mouth.

questions.text: 43-year-old man complains of hearing loss. He has had multiple bouts of ear infections over the last sixteen years and was recently diagnosed with chronic suppurative otitis media. Which of the following is the most likely complication of this condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
CHOLESTEATOMA:-

  • Non-neoplastic, cystic lesions associated with chronic otitis media.
  • cysts are typically 1 to 4 cm in diameter
  • It is a complication of chronic suppurative otitis and a rupture of the eardrum.
  • Chronic inflammation and perforation of the eardrum, with ingrowth of the squamous epithelium or metaplasia of the secretory epithelial lining of the middle ear, promote formation of a squamous cell nest that becomes cystic.
  • Cyst rupture induces a brisk inflammatory reaction that includes giant cells engulfing partially necrotic squamous cells and other particulate debris. These lesions, by progressive enlargement, can erode into the ossicles, labyrinth, adjacent bone, or surrounding soft tissue and sometimes produce visible neck masses.
  • Cholesteatoma is a mass of accumulated keratin and squamous mucosa that results from the growth of squamous epithelium from the external ear canal through the perforated eardrum into the middle ear.
  • Microscopically:-
  • It is surrounded by granulation tissue and fibrosis.
  • lined by keratinizing squamous or metaplastic mucus-secreting epithelium, and filled with amorphous, keratinous debris.
  • Cholesterol spicules may be present.
  • The keratin mass frequently becomes infected and shields the bacteria from antibiotics.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Chronic inflammation and perforation of the eardrum, with ingrowth of the squamous epithelium or metaplasia of the secretory epithelial lining of the middle ear, promote formation of a squamous cell nest that becomes cystic.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman complains of gradual hearing loss. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of conducting hearing loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
OTOSCLEROSIS refers to the formation of new spongy bone (ABNORMAL BONE DEPOSITION) in the middle ear about the rim of the oval window into which the footplate of the stapes fits, which results in progressive deafness.

  • Autosomal dominant hereditary defect
  • Both ears are usually affected.
  • Represent uncoupling of normal bone resorption and bone formation.
  • At first, there is fibrous ankylosis of the footplate. This often occurs in the early decades of life.
  • Over time, bony overgrowth anchors the footplate into the oval window.
  • The severity of the hearing loss reflects the degree of immobilization.
  • The most common cause of conductive hearing loss in young and middle-aged adults
  • The process is slowly progressive over the span of decades and can eventually lead to marked hearing loss.
  • The other choices are much less common causes of hearing loss.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Otosclerosis is an abnormal bone remodelling condition of the otic capsule, commonly affecting the stapes bone, leading to progressive conductive hearing loss.

choices.text: Ganglion nodosum of the vagus nerve

questions.text: Which of the following paraganglioma location is not innervated by parasympathetic system?
questions.solution:
PARAGANGLIOMA

  • Arise from neuroendocrine cells associated with the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems
  • ADRENAL MEDULLARY PHEOCHROMOCYTOMAS are the most common paraganglioma.
  • Approximately 70% of extra-adrenal paragangliomas occur in the head and neck.
  • Loss-of-function mutations in genes encoding succinate dehydrogenase subunits.
  • Paragangliomas typically develop in two locations:
  • PARAVERTEBRAL PARAGANGLIA (e.g., organ of Zuckerkandl and, rarely, bladder).
  • Such tumors have sympathetic connections and stain positively for chromaffin, which detects cells producing catecholamines.
  • Paraganglia related to the great vessels of the head and neck, the so-called AORTICOPULMONARY CHAIN, include
  • Carotid bodies (i.e., carotid body tumor)
  • Aortic bodies
  • Jugulotympanic ganglia (sometimes referred to as glomus tympanicum or jugulare)
  • Ganglion nodosum of the vagus nerve
  • Clusters located about the oral cavity, nose, nasopharynx, larynx, and orbit
  • These are innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system and only rarely produce catecholamines.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Paragangliomas arise from neuroendocrine cells associated with the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems

questions.text: A 62 years old smoker has a right parotid gland swelling since last six months. The resection was done and the microscopic images are given below. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
WARTHIN TUMOR (PAPILLARY CYSTADENOMA LYMPHOMATOSUM)

  • The second most common salivary gland neoplasm (first most common- pleomorphic adenoma)
  • Arises almost exclusively in the parotid gland.
  • Benign, M>F, 5th to 6th decades of life.
  • The risk is increased eightfold in smokers.
  • Unifocal, but about 10% are multifocal and 10% bilateral.
  • Gross :- Round to oval encapsulated masses, 2 to 5 cm in diameter, and readily palpable within the superficial parotid gland. Cut section:- pale gray surface punctuated by narrow cystic or cleftlike spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions and frequently narrowed by polypoid projections of lymphoepithelial elements.
  • Light microscopy:- The lining is composed of a double layer of oncocytic cells;
  • The innermost layer is columnar
  • The outer layer is of cuboidal cells
  • The term oncocyte (or swollen cell in greek) refers to large cells containing numerous mitochondria that impart a granular, eosinophilic appearance to the cytoplasm and have large nuclei with prominent nucleoli.
  • Secretory cells dispersed in the inner layer account for secretions within the dilated lumen.
  • Foci of squamous metaplasia may be present.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Warthin tumor, also known as papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is a benign salivary gland tumor that typically arises in the parotid gland and is the second most common benign salivary gland tumor after pleomorphic adenoma.

questions.text: A middle aged female came to ENT specialist with clinical signs of epistaxis and nasal obstruction since past few days. The doctor found a mass in the superior aspect of nasal cavity. The light microscopic image of the mass is given below. The immunohistochemistry marker showed immunoreactivity for CD56, synaptophysin, chromogranin and NSE. What could be the possibile diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OLFACTORY NEUROBLASTOMA (ESTHESIONEUROBLASTOMA).

  • Arise from neuroectodermal olfactory cells within the mucosa, particularly in the superior aspect of the nasal cavity.
  • Bimodal age distribution:- with peaks at 15 and 50 years.
  • Signs and symptoms:- nasal obstruction and/or epistaxis.
  • Histologically:-
    • olfactory neuroblastomas are SMALL, BLUE, ROUND CELL NEOPLASMS, (includes lymphoma, small cell carcinoma, Ewing sarcoma/ peripheral neuroectodermal tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, melanoma, and sinonasal undifferentiated carcinoma)
    • well-circumscribed nests and lobules of cells separated by fibrovascular stroma.
    • A fibrillary matrix, representing tangled neuronal cell processes, is often present. Consistent with their neuroendocrine origin,
  • Electron microscopy demonstrates membrane-bound secretory granules
  • Immunohistochemistry :- positive for neuron-specific enolase, synaptophysin, CD56, and chromogranin.
  • Depending on tumor stage and grade, combinations of surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy yield 5-year survival rates of 40% to 90%.
  • Genetic aberrations in olfactory neuroblastoma are heterogenous, with cases demonstrating varying chromosomal gains and/or losses.

KEY TAKEWAYS: A rare neuroectodermal tumor originating from the olfactory epithelium in the upper nasal cavity.

Diagnosis

  1. Imaging:
    • CT: Erosion of the cribriform plate.
    • MRI: Soft tissue mass with intracranial extension.
  2. Histopathology:
    • Small round blue cells with neurofibrillary background.
    • Rosettes (Homer Wright rosettes).
  3. Immunohistochemistry:
    • Positive: Neuron-specific enolase (NSE), synaptophysin, chromogranin.
    • Negative: Cytokeratin (to exclude carcinoma).

Mnemonic for Clinical Features: "NOSE"

  • N: Nasal obstruction.
  • O: Orbital symptoms.
  • S: Smell loss.
  • E: Epistaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a developmental odontogenic cyst?
questions.solution:
Odontogenic cysts are derived from remnants of odontogenic epithelium present within the jaws.

  • epithelial-lined cysts are common in the jaws.
  • These cysts are subclassified as either inflammatory or developmental
  • THE DENTIGEROUS CYST:- (choice C)
    • Originates around the crown of an unerupted tooth
    • Fluid accumulation between the developing tooth and the dental follicle.
    • Radiographically :- Unilocular lesions most often associated with impacted third molar (wisdom) teeth.
    • Histologically:- Lined by a thin layer of stratified squamous epithelium, dense chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate in surrounding connective tissue.
    • Treatment:- Complete surgical excision
  • RADICULAR CYST:- (choice B)
    • Common inflammatory lesion found at the tooth apex.
    • The cysts develop as a result of longstanding inflammation of the tooth (pulpitis), often secondary to advanced carious lesions or local trauma.
    • Necrosis of the pulp tissue traverse the length of the root to exit at the apex into the surrounding alveolar bone.
    • Over time, granulation tissue may develop, with subsequent epithelialization that results in a radicular cyst.
  • ERUPTION CYST :- (choice D)
    • Subtype of dentigerous cyst
    • unilateral or bilateral, single or multiple
    • gingival swelling above erupting primary or, rarely, permanent teeth.
    • Microscopy -subacutely inflamed and hemorrhagic cyst wall lined by usually thin and nonkeratinizing stratified squamous epithelium.
  • GINGIVAL CYSTS OF NEWBORN INFANTS (BOHN NODULES) (choice A)
    • minute cystic or nodular formations
    • Seen in neonates and gradually disappear, usually in a matter of weeks.
    • Microscopically, they are lined by stratified squamous epithelium that are sometimes parakeratotic. Occasionally, gingival cysts are seen in adults.
